etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin orientalis, from orient- (see orient)

notes.text: The term Oriental, denoting a person from East Asia, is regarded as offensive by many Asians, especially Asian Americans. It has many associations with European imperialism in Asia. Therefore, it has an out-of-date feel and tends to be associated with a rather offensive stereotype of the people and their customs as inscrutable and exotic. Asian and more specific terms such as East Asian, Chinese, and Japanese are preferred. See also Asian

definitions: of, from, or characteristic of Asia, especially East Asia
shortDefinitions: of or characteristic of East Asia

definitions: relating to or denoting a zoogeographical region comprising Asia south of the Himalayas and Indonesia west of Wallace's line. Distinctive animals include pandas, gibbons, tree shrews, tarsiers, and moonrats.
(of a pearl or other jewel) orient.

definitions: a person of East Asian descent.
